thread.title: Camberwell, Victoria adds nightlife to lifestyle mix
thread.title_full: Camberwell, Victoria adds nightlife to lifestyle mix | afr.com

author: Nicole Haddow
title: Camberwell, Victoria adds nightlife to lifestyle mix
text:
Agent and auctioneer Doug McLauchlan of Marshall White Real Estate in action during the auction for the property at 27-29 Kintore Street in Camberwell on September 19, 2015. Josh Robenstone by Nicole Haddow In many respects Camberwell, in Melbourne's east, is frozen in time. A significant portion of the leafy suburb is protected by heritage overlay, which means some streetscapes have barely changed for the best part of a century. The Rivoli cinema and Our Lady of Victories Basilica are superb examples of the preserved historic architecture. Until May 2015, residents voted in restaurant liquor licensing polls. The discontinuation ends a 95-year dry-zone regulation. Now the Victorian Commission for Gambling and Liquor Regulation (VCGLR) will manage applications. Late-night entertainment has traditionally been minimal, but there is a desire for progression in this area.
Families are attracted to the Victorian and Californian bungalows on large blocks. There are a number of elite private schools in the neighbourhood. It is serviced by three tramlines that all move through Camberwell Junction, the suburb's heart. In recent years, many new cafes and boutiques have opened. The sprawling parks and gardens are popular, with 16 parks making up 5 per cent of the suburb.
Who buys Couples with children make up 50 per cent of the population and the predominant age group is zero to 14 years. People settling in this suburb tend to stay, which is why, of the 20,000 residents, 24 per cent are couples with children. Home owners are generally affluent professionals, with 22 per cent earning between $130,000 and $180,000 annually and 16.5 per cent earning more than $180,000, Core Logic data shows. "Camberwell is a fantastic family area," Kay & Burton agent Dave Oster says. "People move here due to the many amenities on offer."
Camberwell Junction, in Melbourne's east. Michael Rayner Market overview Home owners are likely to pay more than $4000 a month on mortgage repayments and the median sale price is $1.7 million, up from $1.47 million 12 months ago, Core Logic data shows. In the past 12 months 302 properties have sold and they were on the market for an average of 72 days. Owner-occupiers make up 31 per cent of residents and 45 per cent own their property outright. Twenty-one per cent of residents are renters. The median rent is $730 a week.
In focus Builder and developer James Permezel is selling his Victorian mansion near Camberwell Junction. It has city views, seven bedrooms, three bathrooms, formal living and dining rooms, and a rumpus room, study, solar pool and spa. Additional features include an outdoor kitchen, cellar, hydronic heating, zoned cooling, auto gates and parking for four vehicles. It is close to restaurants, shops and good schools. Dave Oster, of Kay & Burton, is quoting more than $5 million.
 Weigh it up Pros
Many parks and gardens
Good public transport
Historic homes on generous blocks
Cons
Some development occurring
Limited nightlife
